text: Learn how to learn from those who disagree with you or even offend you. See if you can find truth in what they believe.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Being enthusiastic is worth 25 IQ points.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Always demand a deadline. A deadline weeds out the extraneous and the ordinary and it prevents you from trying to make it perfect so you have to make it different. Different is much better.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Don't be afraid to ask a question that may sound stupid because 99% of the time everyone else is thinking of that same question and is too embarrassed to ask it.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Being able to listen well is a superpower. While listening to someone you love, keep asking them "Is there more?" until there is no more.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: A worthy goal for a year is to learn enough about a subject so that you can't believe how ignorant you were a year earlier.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Gratitude will unlock all other virtues and is something you can get better at.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Treating a person to a meal never fails and is so easy to do. It's powerful with old friends and it's a great way to make new friends.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Don't trust all-purpose glue.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Reading to your children regularly will bond you together and will kick-start their imaginations.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Never use a credit card for credit. The only kind of credit or debt that's acceptable is debt to acquire something whose value will increase over time — like a house. The exchange value of most things diminishes or vanishes the moment you purchase them so don't be in debt to losers.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Pros are just amateurs who know how to gracefully recover from their mistakes.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Extraordinary claims should require extraordinary evidence to be believed.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Don't be the smartest person in the room. Hang out with, and learn from, people smarter than yourself. Even better, find smart people who will disagree with you.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Rule of three in conversation. To get to the real reason, ask a person to go deeper than what they have just said, then again, and then once more. The third time's answer is close to the truth.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Don't be the best. Be the only.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Everyone is shy. Other people are waiting for you to introduce yourself to them, they want you to send them an email, they are waiting for you to ask them on a date. So go ahead.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Don't take it personally when someone turns you down. Assume they are just like you — occupied, distracted. Try again later. It's amazing how often a second try works.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: The purpose of the habit is to remove that action from self negotiation. You no longer expend energy deciding whether to do it, you just do it. Good habits can range from telling the truth to flossing.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Promptness is a sign of respect.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: When you're young, spend at least six months to one year living as poor as you can, owning as little as you possibly can, eating beans and rice in a tiny room or tent to experience what your worst lifestyle may be. That way, when you have something in the future that you want to risk, you won't be afraid of the worst-case scenario.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Trust me: there is no "them".
author: Kevin Kelly

text: The more that you are interested in others, the more interesting they find you. So to be interesting, be interested.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Optimize your generosity. No one on their deathbed has ever regretted giving away too much.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: To make something good, just do it. To make something great, just re-do it, re-do it, re-do it. The secret to making fine things is in remaking them.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: The golden rule will never fail you. It is the foundation of all the other virtues.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: If you're looking for something in your house and then you finally find it, when you're done with it, don't put it back where you found it, put it back where you first looked for it.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Saving money and investing money are good habits. Small amounts of money invested very regularly for many decades without deliberation is one path to wealth.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: To make mistakes is human. To own your mistakes is divine. Nothing elevates a person higher than quickly admitting and taking personal responsibilities for the mistakes that you make and then fixing them fairly. If you mess up, fess up. It's astounding how powerful this ownership is.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Never get involved in a land war in Asia.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: You can obsess about serving your customers, clients, audiences, or you can obsess about beating the competition. Both work. But of the two, obsessing about your customers will take you much further.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Show up. Keep showing up. Somebody successful once said '99% of success is just showing up.'
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Separate the process of creation from improving. You can't write and edit, or sculpt and polish, or make and analyze at the same time. If you do, the editor stops the creator. While you invent, don't select. While you sketch, don't inspect. While you write the first draft, don't reflect. At the start the creator mind must be unleashed from judgment.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: If you're not falling down occasionally, you're just coasting.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Perhaps the most counterintuitive truth of the universe is that the more you give to others, the more you'll get. Understanding that is the beginning of wisdom.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Friends are better than money. Almost anything that money can do, friends can do better. In so many ways, a friend with a boat is better than owning a boat.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: This is true: it is hard to cheat an honest man.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: When an object is lost, 99% of the time it is hiding within arm's reach of where it was last seen. So, search in all possible locations in that radius and you'll find it.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: You are what you do. Not what you say, not what you believe, not how you vote, but what you spend your time on.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: If you lose or forget to bring a cable and adapter or charger, check with your hotel. Most hotels have a drawer full of cables, adapters, and chargers that others have left behind and probably have the one that you want if you can claim it after you borrow it.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Hatred is a curse that does not affect the hated. It only affects the hater. So release a grudge as if it was poison.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: There is no limit on better. Talent is unevenly distributed, but there is no limit on how much we can do with what we start with.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Be prepared. When you are 90% done any large project, like a house, a film, an event, an app, the rest of the myriad details will take a second 90% to complete.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: When you die, you take absolutely nothing with you except your reputation.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Before you are old attend as many funerals as you can bear and listen. Nobody talks about the departed's achievements. The only thing people mention is what kind of person you were while you were achieving.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: For every dollar you spend purchasing something substantial, expect to pay a dollar in repairs, maintenance, or disposal, by the end of its life.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Anything real begins with a fiction of what it could be. Imagination therefore is the most potent force in the universe and a skill you can get better at. It's the one skill in life that benefits from ignoring what everybody else knows.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: When crisis and disaster strike, don't waste them. No problems, no progress.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: On vacation, go to the most remote place on your itinerary first, bypassing the cities. You'll maximize the shock of otherness in the remote and then later you'll welcome the familiar comforts of a city on the way back.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: When you get an invitation to do something in the future, ask yourself, 'Would I accept this if it was scheduled for tomorrow?' Not too many promises will pass that immediacy filter.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Don't say anything about someone in an email that you would not be comfortable saying to them directly because eventually they will read it.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: If you desperately need a job, you are just another problem for a boss. But if you can solve many of the problems the boss has right now, you are hired. To be hired, think like your boss.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Art is in what you leave out.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Acquiring things will rarely bring you deep satisfaction, but acquiring experiences will.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Rule of 7 in research: you can find out almost anything if you're willing to go seven levels. If the first source you ask doesn't know, then you ask them who you should ask next. And so on, down the line. If you're willing to do that to the seventh source, you will almost always get your answer.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: How to apologize? Quickly, specifically, sincerely.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Don't ever respond to a solicitation or proposal on the phone. The urgency is a disguise.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: When someone is nasty, or rude, or hateful, or mean with you, pretend that they have a disease. That makes it easier to have empathy towards them which can often soften the conflict.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Eliminating clutter makes room for your true treasures.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: You don't really want to be famous. Read the biography of any famous person.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Experience is overrated. When hiring, hire for aptitude, train for skills. Most really amazing or great things have been done by people doing them for the very first time.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: A vacation plus a disaster equals an adventure.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Buying tools? Start with buying the absolute cheapest tools you can find. Upgrade the ones that you use a lot. If you wind up using something as a tool for a job, buy the very best you can afford.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Learn how to take a twenty minute power nap without embarrassment.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Following your bliss is a recipe for paralysis if you don't know what you are passionate about. A better motto for most youth is to master something. Anything. Through mastery of one thing you can drift towards extensions of that mastery that bring you more joy and eventually you'll discover where your bliss is.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: I'm positive that in one hundred years much of what I take to be true today will be proved to be wrong. Maybe even embarrassingly wrong. And I try really hard to identify what it is that I am wrong about today.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Over the long term, the future is decided by optimists. To be an optimist you don't have to ignore the many problems we create. You have to imagine improving our capacity to solve those problems.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: The universe is conspiring behind your back to make you a success. This would be much easier to do if you embrace this paranoia.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: The best way to criticize something is to make something better.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Admitting that "I don't know" at least once a day will make you a better person.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Forget trying to decide what your life's destiny is. That's too grand. Instead, just figure out what you should do in the next 2 years.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Aim to be effective, but unpredictable. That is, you want to act in a way that AIs have trouble modeling or imitating. That makes you irreplaceable.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Whenever you hug someone, be the last to let go.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Don't save up the good stuff (fancy wine, or china) for that rare occasion that will never happen; instead use them whenever you can.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: The best gardening advice: find what you can grow well and grow lots and lots of it.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Never hesitate to invest in yourself—to pay for a class, a course, a new skill. These modest expenditures pay outsized dividends.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Try to define yourself by what you love and embrace, rather than what you hate and refuse.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Read a lot of history so you can understand how weird the past was; that way you will be comfortable with how weird the future will be.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: To make a room luxurious, remove things, rather than add things.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Interview your parents while they are still alive. Keep asking questions while you record. You'll learn amazing things. Or hire someone to make their story into an oral history, or documentary, or book. This will be a tremendous gift to them and to your family.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: If you think someone is normal, you don't know them very well. Normalcy is a fiction. Your job is to discover their weird genius.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: When shopping for anything physical (souvenirs, furniture, books, tools, shoes, equipment), ask yourself: where will this go? Don't buy it unless there is a place it can live. Something may need to leave in order for something else to come in.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: You owe everyone a second chance, but not a third.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: When someone texts you they are running late, double the time they give you. If they say they'll be there in 5, make that 10; if 10, it'll be 20; if 20, count on 40.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Multitasking is a myth. Don't text while walking, running, biking or driving. Nobody will miss you if you just stop for a minute.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: You can become the world's best in something primarily by caring more about it than anyone else.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Asking "what-if?" about your past is a waste of time; asking "what-if?" about your future is tremendously productive.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Try to make the kind of art and things that will inspire others to make art and things.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Once a month take a different route home, enter your house by a different door, and sit in a different chair at dinner. No ruts.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Where you live—what city, what country—has more impact on your well being than any other factor. Where you live is one of the few things in your life you can choose and change.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Every now and then throw a memorable party. The price will be steep, but long afterwards you will remember the party, whereas you won't remember how much is in your checking account.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Most arguments are not really about the argument, so most arguments can't be won by arguing.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: The surest way to be successful is to invent your own definition of success. Shoot your arrows first and then paint a bull's eye around where they land. You're the winner!
author: Kevin Kelly

text: When remodeling a home interior use big pieces of cardboard to mock-up your alterations at life size. Seeing things, such as counters, at actual size will change your plans, and it is so much easier to make modifications with duct tape and scissors.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: There should be at least one thing in your life you enjoy despite being no good at it. This is your play time, which will keep you young. Never apologize for it.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Changing your mind about important things is not a consequence of stupidity, but a sign of intelligence.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: You have 5 minutes to act on a new idea before it disappears from your mind.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: What is important is seldom urgent and what is urgent is seldom important. To get the important stuff done, avoid the demands of the urgent.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Three situations where you'll never regret ordering too much: when you are pouring concrete, when you are choosing a battery, and when you are getting ice for a party.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: The patience you need for big things, is developed by your patience with the little things.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Don't fear failure. Fear average.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: When you are stuck or overwhelmed, focus on the smallest possible thing that moves your project forward.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: In a museum you need to spend at least 10 minutes with an artwork to truly see it. Aim to view 5 pieces at 10 minutes each rather than 100 at 30 seconds each.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: For steady satisfaction, work on improving your worst days, rather than your best days.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Your decisions will become wiser when you consider these three words: "...and then what?" for each choice.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: If possible, every room should be constructed to provide light from two sides. Rooms with light from only one side are used less often, so when you have a choice, go with light from two sides.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Never accept a work meeting until you've seen the agenda and know what decisions need to be made. If no decisions need to be made, skip the meeting.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: You have no obligation to like everyone, and you are free to intensely dislike a person. But you owe everyone—even those you dislike—basic respect.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: When you find yourself procrastinating, don't resist. Instead lean into it. Procrastinate 100%. Try to do absolutely nothing for 5 minutes. Make it your job. You'll fail. After 5 minutes, you'll be ready and eager to work.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: If you want to know how good a surgeon is, don't ask other doctors. Ask the nurses.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: There is a profound difference between thinking less of yourself (not useful), and thinking of yourself less (better).
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Strong opinions, clearly stated, but loosely held is the recipe for an intellectual life. Always ask yourself: what would change my mind?
author: Kevin Kelly

text: You cannot truly become yourself by yourself. Becoming one-of-a-kind is not a solo job. Paradoxically you need everyone else in the world to help make you unique.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: If you need emergency help from a bystander, command them what to do. By giving them an assignment, you transform them from bewildered bystander to a responsible assistant.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: The most common mistake we make is to do a great job on an unimportant task.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Don't work for a company you would not invest money in, because when you are working you are investing the most valuable thing you have: your time.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Fail fast. Fail often. Fail forward. Failing is not a disgrace if you keep failing better.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Doing good is its own reward. When you do good, people will question your motive, and any good you accomplish will soon be forgotten. Do good anyway.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Best sleep aid: first, get really tired.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: For every success there is a corresponding non-monetary tax of some kind. To maintain success you have to gladly pay these taxes.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Do not cling to a mistake just because you spent a lot of time making it.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: For small tasks the best way to get ready is to do it immediately.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: If someone is calling you to alert you to fraud, nine out of ten times they are themselves the fraudster. Hang up. Call the source yourself if concerned.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: When you try to accomplish something difficult, surround yourself with friends.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: You should be willing to look foolish at first, in order to look like a genius later.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Think in terms of decades, and act in terms of days.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: The most selfish thing in the world you can do is to be generous. Your generosity will return you ten fold.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Discover people whom you love doing "nothing" with, and do nothing with them on a regular basis. The longer you can maintain those relationships, the longer you will live.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Forget diamonds; explore the worlds hidden in pebbles. Seek the things that everyone else ignores.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Write your own obituary, the one you'd like to have, and then everyday work towards making it true.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Avoid making any kind of important decision when you are either hungry, angry, lonely, or tired (HALT). Just halt when you are HALT.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: What others want from you is mostly to be seen. Let others know you see them.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Working differently is usually more productive than working harder.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: When you try something new, don't think of it as a matter of success / failure, but as success / learning to succeed.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: If you have a good "why" to live for, no "how" will stop you.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: If you are out of ideas, go for a walk. A good walk empties the mind—and then refills it with new stuff.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: The highest form of wealth is deciding you have enough.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Education is overly expensive. Gladly pay for it anyway, because ignorance is even more expensive.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: The cheapest therapy is to spend time with people who make you laugh.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Always be radically honest, but use your honesty as a gift not as a weapon. Your honesty should benefit others.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: A good sign that you are doing the kind of work you should be doing is that you enjoy the tedious parts that other people find tortuous.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Being envious is a toxin. Instead take joy in the success of others and treat their success as your gain. Celebrating the success of others costs you nothing, and increases the happiness of everyone, including you.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: The more persistent you are, the more chances you get to be lucky.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: To tell a good story, you must reveal a surprise; otherwise it is just a report.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Small steps matter more when you play a long game because a long horizon allows you to compound small advances into quite large achievements.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: If you are more fortunate than others, build a longer table rather than a taller fence.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Many fail to finish, but many more fail to start. The hardest work in any work is to start. You can't finish until you start, so get good at starting.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Work on your tone. Often ideas are rejected because of the tone of voice they are wrapped in. Humility covers many blemishes.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: When you are right, you are learning nothing.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Very small things accumulate until they define your larger life. Carefully choose your everyday things.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: It is impossible to be curious and furious at the same time, so avoid furious.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: College is not about grades. No one cares what grades you got in college. College is about exploring. Just try stuff.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Weird but true: If you continually give, you will continually have.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: To clean up your city, sweep your doorstep first.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Decisions like to present themselves as irreversible, like a one-way door. But most deciding points are two-way. Don't get bogged down by decisions. You can usually back up if needed.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Every mistake is an opportunity to improvise.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: You'll never meet a very successful pessimistic person. If you want to be remarkable, get better at being optimistic.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: You can't call it charity unless no one is watching.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: When you think of someone easy to despise—a tyrant, a murderer, a torturer—don't wish them harm. Wish that they welcome orphans into their home, and share their food with the hungry. Wish them goodness, and by this compassion you will increase your own happiness.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Get good at being corrected without being offended.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: The week between Christmas and New Years was invented to give you the perfect time to sharpen your kitchen knives, vacuum your car, and tidy the folders on your desktop.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: There is no formula for success, but there are two formulas for failure: not trying and not persisting.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: We tend to overrate the value of intelligence. You need to pair your IQ with other virtues. The most important things in life can not be attained through logic only.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: If you are impressed with someone's work, you should tell them, but even better, tell their boss.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: In matters of the heart, one moment of patience can save you years of regret.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Humility is mostly about being very honest about how much you owe to luck.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Slow progress is still a million times better than no progress.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: Recipe for greatness: expect much of yourself and little of others.
author: Kevin Kelly

text: The very best way to win a friend is to be one.
author: Kevin Kelly
